questions.question: Question 1: What is blood pressure?
questions.explanation: Blood pressure is defined as cardiac output X peripheral resistance.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the SI unit of blood pressure?
questions.explanation: The SI unit of blood pressure is Pascal (Pa). It is conventionally expressed in mm of Hg. Note: 1 mmHg = 133 Pa.

questions.question: Question 3: What is mean arterial pressure?
questions.explanation:
Mean arterial pressure is diastolic + 1/3rd pulse pressure. The mean pressure is the average pressure throughout the cardiac cycle. It is not equal to the 
average of systolic and diastolic pressure because, at normal heart rates, a greater fraction of the 
cardiac cycle is spent in diastole than in systole. The mean arterial pressure is therefore 
determined by about 60 percent by the diastolic pressure and 40 percent by the systolic pressure. Mean BP= DBP + 1/3 Pulse pressure = DBP +1/3(SBP- DBP) = (3DBP+SBP- DBP)/3 = 2/3 DBP + 1/3 SBP

questions.question:
Question 4: Korotkoffs sounds are due to  
.

options.a: Increased laminar flow on application of pressure
options.b: Closure of aortic valve in diastole
options.c: Arterial turbulence on occlusion of vessel
options.d: Normal sound that exist even without application of cuff

questions.explanation:
Korotkoffs sounds are due to arterial turbulence on occlusion of the vessel. 545 
Sold by @itachibot The streamline flow in the unconstricted artery is silent. But when the artery is narrowed, the 
velocity of flow through the constriction exceeds the critical velocity and turbulent flow results. 
Turbulent flow in the partly occluded brachial artery sets up the vibrations (oscillations) of the 
vessel wall which are heard through the stethoscope and are known as Korotkoffs sounds.

questions.question:
Question 5: When measuring blood pressure, which of the following is unlikely to show a spuriously high 
BP?
questions.explanation:
The auscultatory gap may give a falsely low recording of systolic BP and overestimation of 
diastolic blood pressure not spuriously high BP. In older patients with wide pulse pressure and in some hypertensive patients, the Korotkoff 
sounds may become inaudible between SBP and DBP, and reappear as cuff deflation continues, 
this is known as auscultatory gap. Small cuff size, obesity, and thick calcified arteries can give rise to falsely high BP as in these 
conditions, vessels are difficult to compress and higher cuff pressure is required to compress 
them.

questions.question: Question 6: The systolic pressure in the right ventricle is
questions.explanation: The systolic pressure in the right ventricle is about 25 mmHg.

questions.question: Question 7: During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by:
questions.explanation:
During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by the elastic recoil of aorta. There is stretching of aorta and arteries during systole due to ejection of blood from ventricle. 
During diastole, the previously stretched aorta and arteries recoil. The volume of blood that is 
displaced by the recoil furnishes continuous capillary flow throughout diastole.

questions.question: Question 8: The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by
questions.explanation:
The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by arterial wall expansion. Arterial Pulse • The blood forced into the aorta during systole not only moves the blood in the vessels forward 
but also sets up a pressure wave that travels along the arteries. The pressure wave expands the 
arterial walls as it travels and the expansion is palpable as the pulse. • The two major factors that influence arterial pulse are- stroke volume of the heart and 
distensibility (compliance) of the vessels. 546 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to
questions.explanation:
The carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to pulse pressure. They fire more rapidly to a 
constantly changing pressure than a stationary one. Baroreceptors • Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels • Types based on location • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions) • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions) • Afferents • Carotid sinus – a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus 
nerve of Hering) • Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the Vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve • Center for Reflex • Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius) • Efferents • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature • Most sensitive to pulsatile pressure: They work to maintain BP in the range of mean BP, but it is 
the changes in the pressure they are the most sensitive to. • The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg • Maximal activity: 180 mmHg • Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors are 
denervated • Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response • 70–110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP 
and HR • >150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of the sympathetic 
nerve is maximal.

questions.question: Question 10: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in
questions.explanation:
Baroreceptor stimulation would result in decreased sympathetic discharge to heart. The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic 
discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. Thus leading to: • Vasodilation and venodilation • Hypotension 547 
Sold by @itachibot • Bradycardia • Decrease in cardiac output

questions.question: Question 11: The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is
questions.explanation:
The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 180 mmHg (arterial 
pressure here and not MAP). The blood pressure range to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 70- 150 mmHg of mean 
arterial pressure.

questions.question: Question 12: Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of:
questions.explanation:
Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of Rostral ventrolateral medulla. The baroreceptors are stimulated by distension of the structures in which they are located. Their 
afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves to the medulla. These fibers release 
glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius (NTS). These NTS neurons 
then excite neurons in the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). These CVLM neurons release the 
inhibitory neurotransmitter -aminobutyric acid (GABA) into the RVLM to reduce the firing rate 
of these. Thus, reducing the sympathetic outflow.

questions.question: Question 13: Baroreceptor provides
questions.explanation:
Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure. Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites 
the vagal innervation of the heart. 548 
Sold by @itachibot Baroreceptor reflex • Increased BP  stimulation of baroreceptors  stimulation of NTS  inhibition of RVLM 
inhibition of sympathetic system • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC  parasympathetic stimulation • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation  decreased HR and BP NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius CVC - Cardiovagal center RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla HR- Heart rate BP - Blood pressure

questions.question: Question 14: Afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control goes to?
questions.explanation:
Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS). Increased BP stimulates the baroreceptors which provide negative feedback in response to the 
increase in blood pressure. Baroreceptor reflex: • Increased BP  stimulation of baroreceptors  stimulation of NTS  excitation of CVLM 
inhibition of RVLM  inhibition of sympathetic system • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC  parasympathetic stimulation • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation  decreased HR and BP NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius CVC - Cardiovagal centre CVLM - Caudal ventrolateral medulla RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla HR - Heart rate BP - Blood pressure

questions.question: Question 15: The low pressure receptors are

options.b: Stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

questions.explanation:
The low-pressure receptors are stimulated by atrial systole and diastole The low-pressure receptors are those in the great veins, right and left atria and pulmonary vessels. Atrial stretch receptors are of two types: • Type A: discharge primarily during atrial systole • Type B: discharge primarily during late diastole 549 
Sold by @itachibot Distension of the atrial wallsstimulation of atrial receptors  Vasodilation, fall in BP and 
increased heart rate.

questions.question: Question 16: Occlusion of common carotid arteries on both sides leads to

options.a: Increase in heart rate and BP
options.b: Increase in BP and decrease in heart rate
options.c: Decrease in heart rate and BP
options.d: No effect on heart rate and BP

questions.explanation:
Occlusion of both common carotid arteries causes an increase in HR and BP. Reduced sinus pressure  response carried to nucleus tractus solitarius via glossopharyngeal and 
vagus nerve  less inhibitory effect on the vasomotor center. This leads to: • Decreased parasympathetic activity to the heart - Increases heart rate • Increased sympathetic activity to the heart and blood vessels - Increases heart rate, contractility, 
constricts arterioles - Increases TPR, constricts veins - increases venous return Note: The carotid baroreceptors are located in the walls of the carotid sinus, which is located at or 
slightly above the bifurcation of the common carotid arteries. So, the occlusion of common carotid 
arteries is occlusion proximal to the carotid sinus. If the occlusion is distal to the carotid sinus increase in sinus pressure  activation of 
baroreceptor reflex  decrease in BP and HR.

questions.question: Question 17: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is
questions.explanation:
The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and 
decreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

questions.question: Question 18: Marey’s law states that

options.a: Heart rate varies directly with blood pressure
options.b: Heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure
options.c: Heart rate do not have any relation with blood pressure
options.d: Heart rate is directly proportional to cardiac output

questions.explanation: Marey’s law states that the heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation?
questions.explanation:
Increased venous capacitance is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation. Important effects of increased sympathetic stimulation: • Arteriolar vasoconstriction • Increased stroke volume • Increased heart rate • Venoconstriction and decrease in venous capacitance 550 
Sold by @itachibot • The increase in mean systemic filling pressure is caused mainly by venous contraction. All these effects together bring about an increased arterial pressure.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is false regarding nitric oxide?
questions.explanation:
Nitric oxide acts by increasing cGMP not by increasing cAMP. Nitric Oxide • Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF). • Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase 
(NOS). • Mechanism of action: NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase   cGMP  relaxation of vascular smooth muscle 
vasodilation. • Effects of NO: • Vasodilation. • Neuromodulator in brain. • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells. • In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle. • Penile erection.

questions.question:
Question 21: 541 
Sold by @itachibot All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except
questions.explanation:
Endothelin-1 • Potent vasoconstrictor agent. • Produced by endothelial cells. • They are secreted locally and act in a paracrine fashion. Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1) • Potent vasoconstrictor. • Platelet activation. • Inotropic effect. • Closure of ductus arteriosus. • Have a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart 
failure. • In the brain, regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB). • In the kidneys, they are involved in tubuloglomerular feedback  GFR. 551 
Sold by @itachibot • In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors). • In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to 
Hirschsprung’s/megacolon). • Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 genecraniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. 
He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an 
erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following 
vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient. Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific 
phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the 
action of NO. Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and 
engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.question: Question 23: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.explanation:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent 
signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted 
back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart 
contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and 
pulmonary circulation. Other options: Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the 
cardiopulmonary region causes profound bradycardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea 
followed by rapid shallow breathing. Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to 
Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and 
hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, 
bradycardia, and irregular respiration. Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary 
receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. On 
examination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for 
elevated blood pressure in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The reflex responsible for elevated blood pressure(BP) in head injury patients is 
the Cushing reflex. 552 
Sold by @itachibot When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is 
compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central 
chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore 
the blood flow to the medulla. Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms: • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors) • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure) • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

questions.question: Question 25: All of the following are rapidly acting blood pressure control mechanisms except:
questions.explanation:
Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is not a rapidly acting pressure control mechanism, 
it is an intermediate-acting mechanism. Regulation of Arterial Blood Pressure: • Rapidly acting pressure control mechanism (acting within sec or min) • The chemoreceptor reflex. • The central nervous system ischemic mechanism. • The baroreceptor reflex. • Intermediate-acting mechanisms (act after minutes) • The capillary fluid shift mechanism. • Stress-relaxation of the vasculature. • The renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism. • Long-term mechanisms (after days) • Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) Note: • Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is an intermediate-acting mechanism, but water 
conservation by RAAS is a long-term mechanism in the regulation of BP. • Most rapidly acting: Baroreceptor reflex>>Chemoreceptor reflex

questions.question: Question 27: Stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors causes:
questions.explanation:
Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies can produce variable effects on heart 
rate- • Direct Effect • vagal stimulation  bradycardia • Indirect effect • Hypoxia peripheral chemoreceptor stimulation hyperventilation and increased 
catecholamine secretion  tachycardia and increased cardiac output Chemoreceptor reflex • Receptors • Peripheral chemoreceptors in carotid and aortic bodies • Central chemoreceptors in the medulla • Stimulus • decrease in- PaO2 • increase in-Pa CO2, H+ ion conc • Afferent 554 
Sold by @itachibot • IX (sinus nerve of Hering) and X (vagus N) • Center for reflex • Medulla • Efferent • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart vasculature and adrenal medulla • Response • Direct effect- bradycardia • Indirect effect- hyperventilation, tachycardia, vasoconstriction, increased cardiac output and 
increased BP

questions.question: Question 28: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.explanation:
Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex. Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, 
atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, 
hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called 
Bezold-Jarisch reflex. Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and 
veratridine.

questions.question:
Question 29: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from 
supine to standing?
questions.explanation:
There is a decreased firing from the baroreceptors. • When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, 
due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output. • Reduced cardiac output, leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing 
from baroreceptors. • As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed leading to increased heart rate. 555 
Sold by @itachibot Gastrointestinal Secretion and Gastrointestinal Hormones
